questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of layers of epidermis from deep to superficial?

choices.text: Stratum basale, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum basale, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum corneum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum basale
Stratum corneum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum basale

questions.solution:
The correct order of the given layers from deep to superficial is stratum basale, stratum spinosum, stratum granulosum, stratum corneum.

 

LAYERS OF SKIN (superficial to deep):

Thin skin

Thick skin

(glabrous skin)

palms, soles, flexor surfaces of digits
  • stratum corneum
  • stratum granulosum
  • stratum spinosum
  • stratum basale
  • stratum corneum
  • stratum lucidum
  • stratum granulosum
  • stratum spinosum
  • stratum basale

Mnemonic for skin layers (superficial to deep): Come Let's Get Some Beer (Corneum, Lucidum, Granulosum, Spinosum, and Basale).

Histologically they appear as follows:

questions.text: Tetanic contraction is due to the accumulation of _______ ions.
questions.solution:
Tetanic contraction occurs due to progressive accumulation of Ca2+ ions with rapidly repeated stimulation of skeletal muscle.

  • With rapidly repeated stimulation, activation of the contractile mechanism occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred, and the individual contractions fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called a tetanus (tetanic contraction).
  • A single action potential releases sufficient Ca2+ to cause a twitch contraction.
  • However, the duration of this contraction is very short because Ca2+ is very rapidly pumped back into the SR.
  • If the muscle is stimulated a second time before the muscle is fully relaxed, there is progressive accumulation of Ca2+ and the force of contraction increases. Thus, twitch forces are amplified as stimulus frequency increases.
  • At a high level of stimulation, intracellular Ca2+ increases and is maintained throughout the period of stimulation, and the amount of force developed greatly exceeds that seen during a twitch. The response is termed tetany.

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is:
questions.solution:
Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is Glucose 6-phosphatase.

A decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is seen in fasting state, in which there is the activation of gluconeogenesis and inhibition of glycolysis.

Among the given options, only glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme of gluconeogenesis and therefore is activated. The enzymes mentioned as other options are irreversible enzymes of glycolysis and are inhibited in the fasting state.

Related Pearl: Enzymes active in phosphorylated and dephosphorylated state

Phosphorylated state

(Low insulin)

Dephosphorylated state

(High insulin)
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • PEP carboxykinase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Glycogen synthase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above image points show lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm which are characteristics of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

 Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

ALL is more common in childhood. The child had symptoms related to depression of marrow function including pallor, weight loss due to anemia and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration.

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population tends to be homogeneous Blast population tends to be heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size is variable, mainly small  Size is variable, mainly large 
Nucleus is central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Nucleus tends to be eccentric, round, oval or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin is fine, with dispersed condensation 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Chromatin is fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli absent in small lymphoblasts 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Nucleoli almost always present, often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm is scanty, basophilic 
Sometimes with a single long projection (‘hand-mirror cell’) 		 Cytoplasm is variable; 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules are rarely present; Negative for peroxidase, esterases and toluidine blue  Granules present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and esoinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods are absent  Auer rods can be present; 
Typically present in the hypergranular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles can be present Vacuoles can be present; 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure which is characteristic of secretory IgA.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient is diagnosed with bilateral renal artery stenosis. He is also on treatment for diabetes mellitus. Which among the following drugs would be the most appropriate for the management of hypertension?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, Verapamil can be used for the management of hypertension in the patient. It does not have any adverse effect on glycemic control.

Option A- ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral artery stenosis. Normally angiotensin II reduces GFR by constricting afferent renal arteriole. However, when there is renal hypotension such as bilateral artery stenosis, it constricts the efferent arteriole thus increasing the GFR. If the RAAS system is blocked in a patient with bilateral renal artery stenosis, the GFR would get reduced significantly and may result in renal failure.

Options C and D- Beta-blockers and thiazides can worsen glycemic control and are not suitable in the given scenario.

questions.text: Late signs of death are all except:
questions.solution:
Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death whereas suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards right indicates
questions.solution:
Weber lateralised towards right indicates right sided conductive deafness or left side sensorineural deafness.

Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out. 

So it is left sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis from the above image is pterygium. 

Pterygium:

It is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.

It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue.

It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. 

It is made up of three parts:

  • a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge),
  • a head,
  • a body.

Occurs due to exposure to radiation: UV-B.

The most common site is nasal.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule, usually
  • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge.
  • Fuchs islets are small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

Treatment: Excision

To prevent recurrence:

Mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil

  • Auto-grafting: Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique has high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery (Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant) has zero rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
• From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color (if not, the inner square is a little darker than the outer circle) and thus cannot be used.
  • Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhoea. The doctor, based on history,  suspects that the child maybe suffering from an infection due to Shigella over cholera and proceeds to give ciprofloxacin as the antibiotic. Which of the following points on history, apart from bloody stools, favour the doctor's suspicion?
questions.solution:
Among the options given, the presence of fever favours the suspicion towards Shigella as the infectious agent, for which ciprofloxacin is the drug of choice.

The presence of vomiting and absence of rectal pain favour cholera and abdominal pain is present in both the diseases.

Symptomatic differential diagnosis of shigella and cholera:

Symptoms Cholera Shigella
Diarrhoea Acute watery Acute bloody
Fever No Yes
Abdominal cramps Yes Yes
Vomiting Yes No
Rectal pain No Yes
Stool >3 loose stools per day, watery like rice water > 3 stools/day, with blood or pus.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than Hypochlorite ion.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Dynamic testing for Cushing’s syndrome
  High dose dexamethasone suppression test CRH stimulation test
Pituitary adenoma Positive (suppressed cortisol) Positive (increase in ACTH and cortisol)
Ectopic ACTH Negative Negative
Iatrogenic: Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing
Adrenal mass or hyperplasia:  Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid. 

Option A: Exogenous steroid administration presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

Option B: Pituitary adenoma presents with elevated ACTH but a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is positive (suppressed).

Option C: Adrenal adenoma presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

Related Pearl: Anti-arrhythmic drugs

Class of antiarrhythmic drugs 

 

Mechanism of action

Effect on action potential duration

Class I

    

Class IA

Procainamide

Quinidine

Disopyramide

 

Na+ channel blockers with significant K+ channel blocking property

 

Prolonged

Class IB

Lidocaine

Mexiletine

 Na+ channel blockers with K+ channel opening property 

Shortened or no effect

Class IC

Flecainide

Propafenone

Moricizine

 Na+ channel blockers with negligible K+ channel blocking property 

Variable or no effect

Class II

    

Propranolol

Esmolol

 β- blockers - 

Class III

    

Amiodarone, dronedarone

Dofetilide

Sotalol

Ibutilide

Vernakalant

 K+ channel blockers  Prolonged 

Class IV

    

Verapamil

Diltiazem

 Ca2+ channel blockers -

Miscellaneous

    

Adenosine

 Activates adenosine receptors Shortened

Digoxin

 Na+-K+ ATPase inhibitor Increases AV node refractoriness

Magnesium

 Unknown -

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis(thrush) is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, bronchi, trachea, or lungs is an AIDS-defining illness.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and KF rings are diagnostic in symptomatic cases of Wilson's disease.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice.

Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 2.5 cm swelling on her neck. The swelling is firm, non-tender, and moves on swallowing. TSH, T3, and T4 levels are normal. An ultrasound reports the swelling to be cystic and regular with low suspicion for malignancy. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform an fine needle aspiration biopsy
Reassure the patient and monitor periodically

questions.solution:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy needs to be performed for further evaluation of the nodule.

In cases where the FNAC is inconclusive, tru-cut or open biopsy can be done. However, this is rarely required.

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following an episode of binge drinking. 7-days post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage.

A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Elevated white blood cell count
  • Abdominal pain

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection.

Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumor penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general):

TNM staging Treatment
T1a Simple cholecystectomy
T1b, T2, T3 Radical cholecystectomy
T4 Unresectable, chemotherapy and palliative nonsurgical therapy are provided
N1 Regional lymphadenectomy
N2 Radical cholecystectomy plus hepatopancreatic duodenectomy


If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy:

  • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would suffice
  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma

TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) guidelines, 8th edition:

TX: Main tumor cannot be assessed due to lack of information

T0: No sign of a primary tumor

Tis: Cancer is only in the epithelium (the inner layer of the gallbladder) and has not grown into deeper layers of the gallbladder.

T1: Tumor invades the lamina propria or the muscle layer (muscularis). 

  T1a:  Tumor invades the lamina propria

  T1b: Tumor invades the muscular layer

T2a: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the peritoneum (the lining of the abdominal cavity). 

T2b: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the liver, but has not invaded the liver.

T3: Tumor invades the serosa and/or it has grown directly into the liver and/or one nearby structure like the stomach, duodenum, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver.

T4: Tumor invades the main blood vessels leading into the liver (portal vein or hepatic artery) or it has grown into 2 or more structures outside the liver.

 

NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed due to lack of information.

N0: Not spread to nearby lymph nodes 

N1: Spread to < 3 nearby lymph nodes

N2: Spread to >4 nearby lymph nodes 

 

M0: Not spread to distant sites 

M1: Tumor spread to distant sites such as the liver, peritoneum (the lining of the abdomen [belly]), or the lungs

 

AJCC Stage Stage grouping
0 TisN0M0
I T1N0M0
IIA T2aN0M0
IIB T2bN0M0
IIIA T3N0M0
IIIB T1-3N1M0
IVA T4N0 or N1M0
IVB Any TN2M0 or Any TAny NM1

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:


In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

The following image shows a voiding cystourethrogram in a patient with grade V VUR:

questions.text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintainence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: Single-dose of a drug used in emergency contraception:
questions.solution:
Single dose of drug used in emergency contraception is Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg.

Levonorgestrel (LNG):

Prostinar tablet contains 0.75 mg LNG. One tablet should be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later. Alternately, two tablets can be taken as a single dose. The failure rate is 1.1%. The tablets can be offered up to 120 h but its efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval. LNG prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency). The period may come earlier or delayed.

Side effects are those of progestogens. The hormone is not teratogenic in case pregnancy does occur but risk of ectopic pregnancy remains.

Advantages:

  • It has no oestrogen and its associated side effects
  • It can be offered to hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic woman
  • It can be offered to a lactating woman
  • It can be given as late as 120 h after the unprotected intercourse
  • Single-dose therapy is an advantage

Contraindicated in liver disease, contains lactate, so allergy to galactose. The drug is also contraindicated in a woman with history of thrombophlebitis and migraine.

This is a high yield MCQ. Various contraception methods and the appropriate beneficiaries of these methods are being tested regularly by AIIMS and NEET exams. Do not forget to revise them before each exam!

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills
Combined pills(COC)

MALA-D(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+Ferrous Fumarate) 

MALA-N(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+ferrous fumarate) Govt supply. Free of cost. 
Progesterone only pills(POP)

Low dosage of progesterone, mainly norethisterone and levonorgestrel

Suitable for lactating women
Once a month(long-acting) pills

Long-acting oestrogen(quinestrol)+ short-acting progesterone

Highly disappointing results
Male pills(Gossypol)

Cottonseed derivative

Causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

Post-coital pills (Interceptive)

 		 Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg tablet within 72 hrs and same dose after 12 hrs OR 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hrs
RU 486(Mifepristone) doses ranging from 10-600mg.
Ulipristal(30 mg) within 5 days
Centchroman: 2 tabs(60 mg) within 24 hrs
 GnRH agonists
CuT IUCD: inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

Progesterone only injectables

 

DMPA: 150 mg IM every 3 months

NET-EN: 200 mg IM every 2 months 

Combined injectables

  

Cyclofem: 25 mg DMPA+5 mg estradiol cypionate

Mesigyna: 50 mg NET-EN+5 mg estradiol valerate 

 

Subdermal implants

Norplant I

35 mg levonorgestrel

Norplant II/Jadelle

Two rods with 70 mg levonorgestrel each and a release rate of 50 mcg/day

Others

Hormonal IUCD

Mirena: 52 mg of LNG with release rate of approx. 20 mcg/day

The patch (ORTHOEVRA)

Norelgestomin+Ethinyl estradiol: Weekly for 3 weeks then patch free 1 week

Vaginal ring (NUVARING)

Etonogestrel+ethinyl estradiol daily release. Use for 3 weeks with a withdrawal week.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child from a draught-ridden village is seen in the medical camp. What is the cause of this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The above skin condition is Flaky paint dermatosis and is seen in Kwashiokar.

These changes commonly occur over the limbs and are characterized by peeling, hyper, and/or hypo-pigmented patches of skin that are crackled.

3 Fs in Kwashiorkor:

  • Fatty liver
  • Flaky paint dermatosis
  • Flag sign - alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strands. (shown below)

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum, known as involucrum. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

Option A: Osteogenic sarcoma characteristically shows the sun-burst appearance and Codman's triangle, as shown below.

 

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma shows an onion-skin appearance of the periosteum, as shown below.

 

Option D: Multiple myeloma shows multiple punched-out lesions of the bone, as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'A' in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an OCD related disorder?
questions.solution:
Temper tantrums are not OCD-related.

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders (as per ICD 11):

It refers to a group of disorders that are characterized by repetitive thoughts and behaviors that share similar etiologies and important diagnostic validators. Important features of these disorders are obsessions, intrusive thoughts, and preoccupations. It includes:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Body focused repetitive behavior disorders (Excoriation, Trichotillomania)

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent inhaled anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The most potent inhaled anesthetic among the given options is halothane, with a minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of 0.75%.

The least potent inhaled anesthetic is nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%.

Note: Methoxyflurane has a MAC of 0.16%, making it more potent than halothane. However, it is obsolete now. The most potent agent overall is methoxyflurane and the most potent agent in clinical use is halothane.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: While collecting data on nail changes in psoriasis patients, you note the following findings. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch (image C), a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. The reddish-brown color is due to dilated, tortuous, superficial capillaries in the papillary dermis and parakeratosis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor. 

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
